Report of Independent Auditors
To the Administrator of United States Steel Corporation Plan for Employee Pension Benefits (Revision of
2003)
Scope and Nature of the ERISA Section 103(a)(3)(C) Audit
We have performed an audit of the accompanying financial statements of United States Steel Corporation
Plan for Employee Pension Benefits (Revision of 2003) (the "Plan"), an employee benefit plan subject to
the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (ERISA), as permitted by ERISA Section
103(a)(3)(C) (ERISA Section 103(a)(3)(C) audit). The financial statements comprise the statements of net
assets available for benefits as of December 31, 2024, and December 31, 2023, and the related statement
of changes in net assets available for benefits for the year ended December 31, 2024, including the related
notes (collectively referred to as the "financial statements").
Management, having determined it is permissible in the circumstances, has elected to have the audit of
the Plan’s financial statements performed in accordance with ERISA Section 103(a)(3)(C) pursuant to 29
CFR 2520.103-8 of the Department of Labor's Rules and Regulations for Reporting and Disclosure under
ERISA. As permitted by ERISA Section 103(a)(3)(C), our audit need not extend to any statements or
information related to assets held for investment of the plan (investment information) by a bank or
similar institution or insurance carrier that is regulated, supervised, and subject to periodic examination
by a state or federal agency, provided that the statements or information regarding assets so held are
prepared and certified to by the bank or similar institution or insurance carrier in accordance with 29 CFR
2520.103-5 of the Department of Labor's Rules and Regulations for Reporting and Disclosure under
ERISA (qualified institution).
Management has obtained certifications from a qualified institution as of December 31, 2024, and
December 31, 2023, and for the years then ended, stating that the certified investment information, as
described in Note 10 to the financial statements, is complete and accurate.
Opinion
In our opinion, based on our audit and on the procedures performed as described in the Auditors'
Responsibilities for the Audit of the Financial Statements section of our report
• the amounts and disclosures in the accompanying financial statements, other than those agreed
to or derived from the certified investment information, are presented fairly, in all material
respects, in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of
America.
• the information in the accompanying financial statements related to assets held by and certified
to by a qualified institution agrees to, or is derived from, in all material respects, the information
prepared and certified by an institution that management determined meets the requirements of
ERISA Section 103(a)(3)(C).
Basis for Opinion
We conducted our audit in accordance with auditing standards generally accepted in the United States of
America (US GAAS). Our responsibilities under those standards are further described in the Auditors'
Responsibilities for the Audit of the Financial Statements section of our report. We are required to be
independent of the Plan and to meet our other ethical responsibilities, in accordance with the relevant
ethical requirements relating to our audit. We believe that the audit evidence we have obtained is
sufficient and appropriate to provide a basis for our ERISA Section 103(a)(3)(C) audit opinion.
PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP, 301 Grant Street, Suite 4500, Pittsburgh, PA 15219
T: (412) 355-6000, www.pwc.com/us

Responsibilities of Management for the Financial Statements
Management is responsible for the preparation and fair presentation of the financial statements in
accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America, and for the
design, implementation, and maintenance of internal control relevant to the preparation and fair
presentation of financial statements that are free from material misstatement, whether due to fraud or
error. Management's election of the ERISA Section 103(a)(3)(C) audit does not affect management's
responsibility for the financial statements.
In preparing the financial statements, management is required to evaluate whether there are conditions
or events, considered in the aggregate, that raise substantial doubt about the Plan's ability to continue as a
going concern for one year after the date the financial statements are available to be issued.
Management is also responsible for maintaining a current plan instrument, including all plan
amendments, administering the plan, and determining that the plan's transactions that are presented and
disclosed in the financial statements are in conformity with the plan's provisions, including maintaining
sufficient records with respect to each of the participants, to determine the benefits due or which may
become due to such participants.
Auditors’ Responsibilities for the Audit of the Financial Statements
Except as described in the Scope and Nature of the ERISA Section 103(a)(3)(C) Audit section of our
report, our objectives are to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements as a
whole are free from material misstatement, whether due to fraud or error, and to issue an auditors' report
that includes our opinion. Reasonable assurance is a high level of assurance but is not absolute assurance
and therefore is not a guarantee that an audit conducted in accordance with US GAAS will always detect a
material misstatement when it exists. The risk of not detecting a material misstatement resulting from
fraud is higher than for one resulting from error, as fraud may involve collusion, forgery, intentional
omissions, misrepresentations, or the override of internal control. Misstatements are considered material
if there is a substantial likelihood that, individually or in the aggregate, they would influence the judgment
made by a reasonable user based on the financial statements.
In performing an audit in accordance with US GAAS, we:
• Exercise professional judgment and maintain professional skepticism throughout the audit.
• Identify and assess the risks of material misstatement of the financial statements, whether due to
fraud or error, and design and perform audit procedures responsive to those risks. Such
procedures include examining, on a test basis, evidence regarding the amounts and disclosures in
the financial statements.
• Obtain an understanding of internal control relevant to the audit in order to design audit
procedures that are appropriate in the circumstances, but not for the purpose of expressing an
opinion on the effectiveness of the Plan's internal control. Accordingly, no such opinion is
expressed.
• Evaluate the appropriateness of accounting policies used and the reasonableness of significant
accounting estimates made by management, as well as evaluate the overall presentation of the
financial statements.
• Conclude whether, in our judgment, there are conditions or events, considered in the aggregate,
that raise substantial doubt about the Plan's ability to continue as a going concern for a
reasonable period of time.
Our audit did not extend to the certified investment information, except for obtaining and reading the
certification, comparing the certified investment information with the related information presented and
disclosed in the financial statements, and reading the disclosures relating to the certified investment

Report of Independent Auditors
To the Administrator of United States Steel Corporation Plan for Employee Pension Benefits (Revision of
2003)
Scope and Nature of the ERISA Section 103(a)(3)(C) Audit
We have performed an audit of the accompanying financial statements of United States Steel Corporation
Plan for Employee Pension Benefits (Revision of 2003) (the "Plan"), an employee benefit plan subject to
the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (ERISA), as permitted by ERISA Section
103(a)(3)(C) (ERISA Section 103(a)(3)(C) audit). The financial statements comprise the statements of net
assets available for benefits as of December 31, 2024, and December 31, 2023, and the related statement
of changes in net assets available for benefits for the year ended December 31, 2024, including the related
notes (collectively referred to as the "financial statements").
Management, having determined it is permissible in the circumstances, has elected to have the audit of
the Plan’s financial statements performed in accordance with ERISA Section 103(a)(3)(C) pursuant to 29
CFR 2520.103-8 of the Department of Labor's Rules and Regulations for Reporting and Disclosure under
ERISA. As permitted by ERISA Section 103(a)(3)(C), our audit need not extend to any statements or
information related to assets held for investment of the plan (investment information) by a bank or
similar institution or insurance carrier that is regulated, supervised, and subject to periodic examination
by a state or federal agency, provided that the statements or information regarding assets so held are
prepared and certified to by the bank or similar institution or insurance carrier in accordance with 29 CFR
2520.103-5 of the Department of Labor's Rules and Regulations for Reporting and Disclosure under
ERISA (qualified institution).
Management has obtained certifications from a qualified institution as of December 31, 2024, and
December 31, 2023, and for the years then ended, stating that the certified investment information, as
described in Note 10 to the financial statements, is complete and accurate.
Opinion
In our opinion, based on our audit and on the procedures performed as described in the Auditors'
Responsibilities for the Audit of the Financial Statements section of our report
• the amounts and disclosures in the accompanying financial statements, other than those agreed
to or derived from the certified investment information, are presented fairly, in all material
respects, in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of
America.
• the information in the accompanying financial statements related to assets held by and certified
to by a qualified institution agrees to, or is derived from, in all material respects, the information
prepared and certified by an institution that management determined meets the requirements of
ERISA Section 103(a)(3)(C).
Basis for Opinion
We conducted our audit in accordance with auditing standards generally accepted in the United States of
America (US GAAS). Our responsibilities under those standards are further described in the Auditors'
Responsibilities for the Audit of the Financial Statements section of our report. We are required to be
independent of the Plan and to meet our other ethical responsibilities, in accordance with the relevant
ethical requirements relating to our audit. We believe that the audit evidence we have obtained is
sufficient and appropriate to provide a basis for our ERISA Section 103(a)(3)(C) audit opinion.

Responsibilities of Management for the Financial Statements
Management is responsible for the preparation and fair presentation of the financial statements in
accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America, and for the
design, implementation, and maintenance of internal control relevant to the preparation and fair
presentation of financial statements that are free from material misstatement, whether due to fraud or
error. Management's election of the ERISA Section 103(a)(3)(C) audit does not affect management's
responsibility for the financial statements.
In preparing the financial statements, management is required to evaluate whether there are conditions
or events, considered in the aggregate, that raise substantial doubt about the Plan's ability to continue as a
going concern for one year after the date the financial statements are available to be issued.
Management is also responsible for maintaining a current plan instrument, including all plan
amendments, administering the plan, and determining that the plan's transactions that are presented and
disclosed in the financial statements are in conformity with the plan's provisions, including maintaining
sufficient records with respect to each of the participants, to determine the benefits due or which may
become due to such participants.
Auditors’ Responsibilities for the Audit of the Financial Statements
Except as described in the Scope and Nature of the ERISA Section 103(a)(3)(C) Audit section of our
report, our objectives are to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements as a
whole are free from material misstatement, whether due to fraud or error, and to issue an auditors' report
that includes our opinion. Reasonable assurance is a high level of assurance but is not absolute assurance
and therefore is not a guarantee that an audit conducted in accordance with US GAAS will always detect a
material misstatement when it exists. The risk of not detecting a material misstatement resulting from
fraud is higher than for one resulting from error, as fraud may involve collusion, forgery, intentional
omissions, misrepresentations, or the override of internal control. Misstatements are considered material
if there is a substantial likelihood that, individually or in the aggregate, they would influence the judgment
made by a reasonable user based on the financial statements.
In performing an audit in accordance with US GAAS, we:
• Exercise professional judgment and maintain professional skepticism throughout the audit.
• Identify and assess the risks of material misstatement of the financial statements, whether due to
fraud or error, and design and perform audit procedures responsive to those risks. Such
procedures include examining, on a test basis, evidence regarding the amounts and disclosures in
the financial statements.
• Obtain an understanding of internal control relevant to the audit in order to design audit
procedures that are appropriate in the circumstances, but not for the purpose of expressing an
opinion on the effectiveness of the Plan's internal control. Accordingly, no such opinion is
expressed.
• Evaluate the appropriateness of accounting policies used and the reasonableness of significant
accounting estimates made by management, as well as evaluate the overall presentation of the
financial statements.
• Conclude whether, in our judgment, there are conditions or events, considered in the aggregate,
that raise substantial doubt about the Plan's ability to continue as a going concern for a
reasonable period of time.
Our audit did not extend to the certified investment information, except for obtaining and reading the
certification, comparing the certified investment information with the related information presented and
disclosed in the financial statements, and reading the disclosures relating to the certified investment

UNITED STATES STEEL CORPORATION PLAN FOR EMPLOYEE PENSION BENEFITS (REVISION OF 2003)
NOTES TO FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
December 31, 2024 and 2023
1. Plan Description
The following description of the United States Steel Corporation Plan for Employee Pension Benefits (Revision of
2003) (the Plan), a defined benefit pension plan, provides only general information. For a more complete description of
the Plan, participants should refer to the General Provisions of the Plan and the various Pension Rules and
Agreements adopted under the Plan, which are available from the United States Steel and Carnegie Pension Fund
(UCF), the Plan Administrator and the Trustee.
a. General — The Plan covers roughly 2,600 active employees, representing approximately 18 percent of
represented and non-represented domestic (US) employees of United States Steel Corporation (the
Company, USS, or the Plan Sponsor) and other employing companies. It does not cover represented
employees (including former National Steel Corporation employees) hired into full-time, regular employment
on or after May 20, 2003, who are covered with defined pension benefits under a multi-employer arrangement
with the Steelworkers Pension Trust. Further, it does not cover non-represented employees (including former
National Steel Corporation employees) hired into full-time, regular employment on or after July 1, 2003. All
participants in the Plan are fully vested. The Plan also covers a large number of retirees, beneficiaries and
surviving spouses of former employees who retired from the current and former steel, diversified and
headquarters operations of the Company. Generally, pension provisions are based on final average earnings
and cover all eligible employees for future retirement, former employees now receiving pensions or entitled to
vested benefits and certain survivors of eligible employees who died while active employees or after
retirement. Pension benefits are calculated using compensation and years of service with a minimum pension
based on years of service. Most non-represented employees in the Plan are also covered by career earnings
provisions. The Company effectuated a hard freeze of benefits accrued effective as of December 31, 2015,
applicable to non-represented employees (affected participants). As a result, from and after December 31,
2015, all benefit accruals under the Plan for affected participants ceased and no affected participant in the
Plan will receive credit under the Plan for further service to the Company or its subsidiaries and the
compensation levels resulting from any such further service will not be relevant to the determination of
benefits payable under the Plan. Final average, minimum and career earnings benefits are provided under
various types of retirement such as normal, early, disability and deferred vested. In addition, a surviving
spouse's benefit is provided. The Plan is subject to the requirements of the Employee Retirement Income
Security Act of 1974, as amended (ERISA) and later pension legislation stemming from the Pension
Protection Act of 2006 (the PPA). Fiduciary responsibility for the Plan is maintained by UCF as the Plan
Administrator and named fiduciary of the Plan.
b. Distributions — The Plan provides several payment options for receiving Plan benefits. A participant may
elect a joint and survivor annuity, life annuity, or, if permitted under the applicable rule part or agreement, a
lump sum, or under certain circumstances, a combination thereof. The Plan provides, in general, for monthly
pensions upon retirement at or after age 65, or earlier upon disability, incapacity, special circumstances, or
with certain minimum age and service requirements. Pension benefits generally depend upon length of
service, job grade or remuneration, and certain social security and other benefits. All annuity payments are
made monthly.
2. Summary of Accounting Policies
a. Basis of accounting — Financial statements are prepared under the accrual method of accounting in
accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America (U.S. GAAP).
b. Use of estimates — The preparation of financial statements in conformity with U.S. GAAP requires
management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amount of assets, liabilities, and
changes therein; disclosure of contingent assets, liabilities and changes therein; and the actuarial present
value of accumulated plan benefits at the date of the financial statements, and changes therein. Actual results
could differ from those estimates.
c. Investment valuation — The Plan’s investments are stated at fair value as defined by Accounting Standards
Codification (ASC) Topic 820, Fair Value Measurements and Disclosures (see Note 14). Fair value is the price
that would be received to sell an asset or paid to transfer a liability in an orderly transaction between market
participants at the measurement date.
The Board of Directors of UCF is responsible for determining the valuation policy and procedures for the Plan.
Northern Trust is the recordkeeper and custodian for the Plan.

UNITED STATES STEEL CORPORATION PLAN FOR EMPLOYEE PENSION BENEFITS (REVISION OF 2003)
NOTES TO FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
December 31, 2024 and 2023
d. Net Appreciation/(Depreciation) — The Plan presents in the accompanying Statement of Changes in Net
Assets Available for Benefits the net appreciation/(depreciation) in the fair value of its investments which
consists of the realized gains or losses and the unrealized appreciation/(depreciation) on those investments.
e. Investment transactions — Transactions are recorded at trade date. All premiums or discounts are
amortized. Interest income is recorded on the accrual basis. Dividends are recorded on the ex-dividend date.
f. Administrative expenses — The Plan’s trustee and administrator is UCF. UCF is a nonprofit membership
corporation responsible for administering and maintaining a system of benefits, pensions or aids to the
employees of United States Steel Corporation and to any successor to it. Except for certain expenses, such
as insurance premiums, paid for by the Plan Sponsor, all expenses, including audit, custodial and tax
preparation fees, incurred in the administration of the Plan are paid out of Plan assets and are recorded as
deductions in the accompanying Statement of Changes in Net Assets Available for Benefits. Expenses paid
by the Plan Sponsor are excluded from these financial statements.
g. Funding policy — The funding policy of the Plan Sponsor provides that payments to pension trusts shall be
no less than the minimum funding requirements of ERISA and the PPA, as amended from time to time, plus
additional amounts which may be approved. USS intends to fund at least the minimum amounts required by
the PPA and may contribute additional voluntary amounts to mitigate future annual requirements. Due to the
Plan funding levels, the Company was not required to make a minimum contribution for the 2024 or 2023
Plan year. The Company did not make any voluntary contributions to the Plan in 2024 or 2023.
h. Payment of benefits — Benefit payments to participants are recorded upon distribution.
3. Actuarial Present Value of Accumulated Plan Benefits
Accumulated Plan benefits are those future periodic payments, including lump-sum distributions, which are attributable
under the Plan's provisions to service which employees have rendered. Accumulated Plan benefits include benefits
expected to be paid to (a) retired or terminated employees or their beneficiaries, (b) beneficiaries of employees who
have died and (c) present employees or their beneficiaries. Accumulated plan benefits for active employees are based
on benefit formulas in effect on the date as of which the benefit information is presented using average earnings as of
such date, or the minimum benefit per year of service provided under the Plan. Benefits payable under all
circumstances (retirement, death, termination and disability) are included, to the extent deemed attributable to
employee service rendered to the valuation date.
The actuarial present value of accumulated Plan benefits is determined by the Plan actuary, Ernst & Young, LLP (EY).
It represents an amount that results from applying actuarial assumptions to adjust accumulated Plan benefits to reflect
the time value of money (through discounts for interest) and the probability of payment (by means of decrements for
death, disability, withdrawal or retirement) between the valuation date and the expected date of payment. The actuarial
valuations as of December 31, 2024 and 2023 were prepared using the accrual method (a unit credit actuarial cost
method) and based upon retirement age assumptions (average retirement age of 62) and a discount rate assumption
of 5.91 percent and 5.50 percent at December 31, 2024 and 2023, respectively. The discount rate is determined by
using a bond matching approach to select specific bonds that would satisfy projected benefit payments. UCF believes
the bond matching approach more closely reflects the process that would be employed to settle its pension obligations.
The Plan uses a custom mortality table based on a plan experience study with a 2019 base year and a modified
MP-2021 mortality improvement scale to measure the pension obligation.
Actuarial assumptions are based on the presumption that the Plan will continue. If the Plan were to terminate, different
actuarial assumptions and other factors would be applicable in determining the actuarial present value of accumulated
plan benefits. The estimated actuarial present value of accumulated plan benefits as is as follows:

6. Plan Amendments
Effective August 28, 2023, the 2023 Pension Agreement under the Plan was amended to reflect the terms of a letter
agreement.
Effective August 1, 2023, the UPI Designated Employees Rules under the Plan were amended to reflect a settlement
agreement and for a miscellaneous technical clarification.
Effective January 1, 2023, the 2023 Pension Agreement under the Plan was adopted as a result of collective
bargaining, legal requirements under federal income tax law and ERISA, plan administration matters, miscellaneous
technical corrections and clarifications and updates, and previously adopted amendments.
Effective January 1, 2023, the UPI Designated Employees Rules and the UPI Non-Union Salaried Rules (UPI Rules)
under the Plan were clarified to refer to the correct rule part name, indicate that the plan sponsor has authority to
amend the UPI rules, and other adjustments.
Effective January 1, 2023, the 2023 Pension Agreement under the Plan was amended to reflect the terms of various
collective bargaining agreements.
The amendments to the Plan did not have a material impact.

7. Tax Status
The Internal Revenue Service (IRS) has determined and informed the Plan Sponsor, by letter dated May 14, 2014, that
the Plan, as amended and restated effective January 1, 2013, continues to qualify under §401(a) of the Internal
Revenue Code of 1986 (IRC), as amended, and its related trust is exempt from tax under §501(a) of the IRC, as
amended. As a result of the Plan’s funding policy, from time to time, the trust may be subject to income taxes. De
minimis state income taxes attributable to unrelated business income have been paid for the 2024 and 2023 tax years.
The Plan has been amended subsequent to the amendments taken into account by the IRS in conjunction with its
issuance of the May 14, 2014, determination letter. The Plan Sponsor and Tax Counsel for the Plan believe the Plan is
designed and is currently being operated in compliance with the applicable requirements of the IRC and therefore,
believe that the Plan is qualified and the related trusts are tax-exempt. No provision for income taxes has been
included in the Plan’s financial statements.
U.S. GAAP requires Plan management to evaluate tax positions taken by the Plan and to recognize a tax liability (or
asset) if the Plan has taken an uncertain tax position that more likely than not would not be sustained upon
examination by the IRS. The Plan Sponsor and Tax Counsel for the Plan has analyzed the tax positions taken by the
Plan and has concluded that as of December 31, 2024 and 2023, there are no uncertain tax positions taken or
expected to be taken that would require recognition of a liability (or asset) or disclosure in the financial statements. The
Plan Administrator believes it is no longer subject to examinations by federal taxing jurisdictions for years prior to 2021.
8. Plan Termination
The Plan Sponsor believes the existence of the Plan is in the best interests of its employees and has no intention of
discontinuing it for eligible employees and other participants already in pay status or deferred vested status. The Plan
Sponsor has reserved the right at its sole discretion to amend or terminate the Rules and Agreements under the Plan,
in whole or in part, as to any or all groups of covered employees subject to applicable collective bargaining
agreements. The portions of the Plan covering employees represented by the USW or other union-represented
collective bargaining agreements can be amended, changed or terminated only by agreement between the Plan
Sponsor and the applicable bargaining unit. However, in the event of plan termination, the net assets available for plan
benefits would be allocated among the participants and beneficiaries of the Plan in the preference order established by
ERISA generally to provide the following benefits in the order indicated:
a. Benefits attributable to employee contributions.
b. Benefits former employees or their beneficiaries have been receiving for at least three years, or employees
eligible for retirement for that three-year period would have been receiving if they had retired. The benefit
amount is limited to the lowest benefit that would be payable under plan provisions in effect at any time during
the five years preceding plan termination.
c. Other vested benefits insured by the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation (PBGC) (a U.S. government
agency) up to the applicable limitations. Summary Plan Descriptions contain detailed information on benefits
insured by the PBGC.
d. All other vested benefits under the Plan (that are not insured by the PBGC).
e. All other benefits under the Plan.
The above allocation would be modified as required by IRC Section 414(l) and applicable regulations for any merger
event that occurs within the 5-year period preceding termination of the plan to ensure that Plan participants do not
receive smaller benefits upon termination due to the merger.
Certain benefits under the Plan are insured by the PBGC if the Plan terminates. Generally, the PBGC guarantees most
vested normal retirement age benefits, early retirement benefits, and certain survivor’s pensions and disability benefits.
However, the PBGC does not guarantee all types of benefits under the Plan, and the amount of benefit protection is
subject to certain limitations. Vested benefits under the Plan are guaranteed at the level in effect on the date of the
Plan’s termination. However, there is a statutory ceiling on the amount of an individual’s monthly benefit that the PBGC
guarantees. The ceiling for Plan terminations occurring during 2024 and 2023, which is adjusted periodically, was
$7,108 and $6,750 per month respectively, payable in the form of a straight life annuity, for a 65-year old person in a
plan that terminates in 2024 and 2023. The maximum benefit may be reduced for an individual who is younger than
age 65. The maximum benefit will also be reduced when a benefit is provided to a survivor of a Plan participant.
Whether all participants receive their benefits should the Plan terminate at some future time will depend on the
sufficiency, at that time, of the Plan’s net assets to provide for accumulated benefit obligations and may also depend
on the financial condition of the Plan Sponsor and the level of benefits guaranteed by the PBGC.

11. Derivatives
The Plan’s investment policy permits derivatives use, consistent with achieving the objectives of the portfolio.
Derivatives that introduce risks not inherently consistent with this policy are prohibited. Derivatives must be managed
such that the portfolio does not incur a leverage effect inconsistent with the objectives. Total portfolio risk, including the
derivatives positions, must remain within the tolerances that could be achieved under these guidelines using only non-
derivative, cash market instruments.
The use of hedging activity to protect against price fluctuations or currency fluctuations is limited to those
circumstances where the activity is tied to a specifically identified investment and must be liquidated upon disposition
of the related investment. Additionally, swaps are permitted to hedge the movement in interest rates used to determine
the Plan’s funded status.

UNITED STATES STEEL CORPORATION PLAN FOR EMPLOYEE PENSION BENEFITS (REVISION OF 2003)
NOTES TO FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
December 31, 2024 and 2023
The Plan enters into contractual arrangements classified as derivatives in carrying out its investment strategy, for the
following purposes: (1) for implementation to manage duration, yield curve exposure and credit exposure and (2) for
purposes of currency hedging of portfolio positions where appropriate.
The futures contracts entered into are for the delayed delivery of securities at a fixed price at a future date or for the
change in the value of a specific financial index over a predetermined time period. Pursuant to the contract, payments
are made to or received from the broker for an amount of cash equal to the daily fluctuation in the value of the contract.
Such receipts are known as variation margin and are recorded on a daily basis. These variation margin payments are
recorded in unrealized earnings until the contract is closed and the corresponding gain or loss is realized. Variation
margin receivables and variation margin payables at period end are included within.
Upon entering into a futures contract, the Plan is required to pledge to the broker an amount of cash or securities equal
to the minimum “initial margin” requirements of the exchange on which the contract is traded. At December 31, 2024
and 2023, the fair value of the assets held in collateral for these futures contracts was $94.5 million and $18.9 million,
respectively, all of which are included within U.S. Government Securities on the Statements of Net Assets Available for
Benefits.
Open futures contracts had an aggregate face value of $1.2 billion and $192.5 million as of December 31, 2024 and
2023, respectively.
12. Risks and Uncertainties
Investments are exposed to various risks, such as interest rate, market and credit risks. Due to the level of risk
associated with these investments and the level of uncertainty related to changes in the value of these investments, it
is at least reasonably possible that changes in the near term could materially affect the amounts reported in the
Statements of Net Assets Available For Benefits and the Statement of Changes in Net Assets Available for Benefits.
The actuarial present value of accumulated plan benefits is prepared based on significant actuarial assumptions,
including discount rates and expected decrements for death, disability, withdrawal and retirement, all of which could
vary from those that occur on an actual basis in the future. Due to uncertainties inherent in the estimation process, it is
at least reasonably possible that changes in the estimates in the near term could be material relative to the actuarial
liabilities disclosed herein.
13. Related Party and Party in Interest Transactions
Fees paid by the Plan to Northern Trust for custodial and accounting services qualify as party-in-interest transactions.
In 2024 and 2023, these fees amounted to $1.4 million and $1.1 million, respectively.
There are no investments of the Plan qualifying as party-in-interest transactions sponsored by Northern Trust.
Any minimum or discretionary contributions made to the Plan by USS are considered party-in-interest transactions. No
such contributions were made in 2024 or 2023.
USS is the Plan Sponsor and provides certain accounting and administrative services for which no fees are charged.
As discussed in Note 2.f., UCF is the Plan’s trustee and administrator. Except for certain expenses paid for by the Plan
Sponsor, all expenses incurred by UCF for the accounting and administration of the Plan are paid out of Plan assets.

NOTES TO FINANCIAL STATEMENTS
December 31, 2024 and 2023
14. Fair Value Measurement
ASC Topic 820 establishes a single definition of fair value, creates a three-tier hierarchy as a framework for measuring
fair value based on inputs used to value the Plan’s investments, and requires additional disclosure about fair value.
The hierarchy gives the highest priority to unadjusted quoted prices in active markets for identical assets or liabilities
(level 1) and the lowest priority to unobservable inputs (level 3). The three levels of the fair value hierarchy are
summarized below.
• Level 1 – Inputs to the valuation methodology are unadjusted quoted prices for identical assets or liabilities in
active markets that the Plan has the ability to access.
• Level 2 – Inputs to the valuation methodology include:
◦ Quoted prices for similar assets or liabilities in active markets;
◦ Quoted prices for identical or similar assets or liabilities in inactive markets;
◦ Inputs other than quoted prices that are observable for the asset or liability;
◦ Inputs that are derived principally from or corroborated by observable market data by correlation or
other means.
If the asset or liability has a specified (contractual) term, the level 2 input must be observable for substantially
the full term of the asset or liability.
• Level 3 – Inputs to the valuation methodology are unobservable and significant to the fair value
measurement.
The Plan’s assets are classified as follows:
Level 1 Level 2
Short-term investments Debt securities
Equity securities U.S. Government securities
Other securities
An instrument’s level is based on the lowest level of any input that is significant to the fair value measurement.
Valuation techniques maximize the use of relevant observable inputs and minimize the use of unobservable inputs.
The following is a description of the valuation methodologies used for assets measured at fair value. There have been
no changes in the methodologies used at December 31, 2024 and 2023. Futures contracts and equity securities are
valued at the closing price reported on the active exchange on which the individual securities are traded. U.S.
Government securities and Debt securities are valued using pricing models maximizing the use of observable inputs
for similar securities. This includes basing values on yields currently available on comparable securities of issuers with
similar credit ratings. Timberland investments, investments in commingled funds, private equities, real estate funds and
mineral interests are valued using net asset value (NAV) as a practical expedient.

Schedule SB, Part V – Statement of actuarial assumptions/methods
Actuarial methods
Measurement Date 1 January
Participant Data 1 January 2024 as provided by the Plan Sponsor
Prescribed interest rates Segment rates representing the 24-month average of corporate bond yields,
for Funding Target adjusted as necessary to fall within a specified range that is determined based on
a percentage of the average of the corresponding segment rates for the 25-year
period ending on September 30 preceding the calendar year that includes the first
day of that plan year with the average to be not less than five percent in
accordance with 430(h)(2)(c)(iv). These rates reflect Interest Rate Relief as
defined in IIJA. The applicable month for the determination of the segment rates is
September.
Actuarial Cost Method Unit Credit Cost Method--This is the prescribed method under PPA. Under this
method a projected benefit is determined at every age at which a participant could
receive a benefit. This benefit is based on accrued service and current pay.
Different benefits will be calculated in accordance with the plan provisions for the
different decrements. The accrued liability is determined by discounting the
benefits to which the employee is expected to become eligible with interest from
the valuation date to the payment date. The normal cost is the difference between
the accrued liability determined as if the participant had an additional year of
service and the otherwise calculated accrued liability.
Asset valuation method The Actuarial Value of Assets for the plan year is determined by averaging the
current year’s fair value of assets with the fair values of assets from the previous
two years adjusted for contributions, benefit payments and expected investment
earnings based on the following:
1. All determination dates that are within 25 months of the valuation date are
used;
2. The determination dates are at the ends of the plan years; and
3. Expected investment earnings are according to the assumptions listed in
Section 6, but limited to the third segment rate used in the calculation of the
Funding Target
The resulting averaged asset value cannot be less than 90% or greater than
110% of the fair value, including receivable contributions.
Decrement timing Middle of the year

30-year Retirement Benefit
Eligibility 30 years of continuous service.
Benefit Formula If the 30-year minimum lifetime pension is not elected, the Normal retirement
pension benefit plus the greater of $400 or the excess of $1,500 over the
normal retirement pension per month payable to the age of eligibility for 80%
of their full Social Security Benefit or Railroad Retirement Benefit (80%
SSNRA or Public Pension Eligible). The increase in pension payable under
this formula shall not exceed the amount of benefits payable to the participant
under the Social Security Act or Railroad Retirement Act when participant
becomes eligible for such benefit.
70/80 Retirement Benefit
Eligibility 15 years of continuous service and (i) age 55 and combined age and years of
continuous service equal 70 or more, or (ii) combined age and years of
continuous service equal 80 or more provided (1) continuous service broken
by reason of a permanent shutdown or a layoff or physical disability, or (2)
absence from work by reason of (i) a layoff resulting from a permanent
shutdown or (ii) a physical disability or a layoff with return to active
employment declared unlikely, or (3) retirement under mutually satisfactory
conditions
Benefit Formula Normal retirement pension plus $400 per month payable until the earlier of
eligibility for a Social Security disability benefit or 80% SSNRA.
Rule of 65 Retirement Benefit
Eligibility Under age 55 with completion of 20 or more years of continuous service and
combined age and years of continuous service equal to 65 or more provided
(1) continuous service broken by reason of a permanent shutdown or a layoff
or physical disability, or (2) absence from work by reason of (i) a layoff
resulting from a permanent shutdown or (ii) a physical disability or a layoff
with return to active employment declared unlikely, or (3) retirement under
mutually satisfactory conditions, and not offered suitable long-term
employment as defined in Appendix A of the Pension Agreement.
Benefit Formula Normal Retirement pension plus $400 per month until the earlier of eligibility
for a Social Security disability benefit or 80% SSNRA, reduced $1.00 for each
$2.00 of the participant's earned income which exceeds $17,000 after
retirement. $17,000 shall be prorated for year of retirement and year
participant becomes Public Pension Eligible.
Terminated Vested Benefit
Eligibility Termination of employment after 5 years of Continuous Service

chooses (1) or (2):
(1) Normal retirement pension benefit deferred to age 62
(2) A pension commencing before age 62 reduced based on
factor in Exhibit C on page 68 of the plan document.

of 1% for each full month, and a pro rate portion thereof for partial months by
which date of early retirement precedes age 62 (but in no event more than 5/9
of 1% for each complete month and a pro rata portion thereof for partial months
by which date of early retirement precedes age 65).
Service after 18 September 2005: Normal retirement pension reduced by 1/4%
for each calendar month pension commences before Normal Retirement

P&M Employees Pension Rules
Open/Closed Closed to new participants on 4 June 1996
Frozen/Accruing Benefit Frozen on 31 December 2008
Normal Retirement Benefit
Eligibility Age 62 with 5 years vesting service for benefit accrued before 18 September
2005 and Age 65 for benefit accrued after 18 September 2005.
Benefit Formula Service before 18 September 2005: $16.50 multiplied by the years of
continuous service, plus $1.50 multiplied by the years of continuous service in
excess of 15 years, plus $4.00 multiplied by the years of continuous service in
excess of 30 years.
Service after 18 September 2005: $50 times years of continuous service and
fraction thereof, for service from 18 September 2005 through freeze date of 31
December 2008.
Early Retirement Benefit
Eligibility Age 60 and 15 years of continuous service for benefit accrued before 18
September 2005 and Age 55 with 5 years of service for benefit accrued after 18
September 2005.
Benefit Formula Service before 18 September 2005: Normal retirement pension reduced by 5/7
of 1% for each full month, and a pro rate portion thereof for partial months by
which date of early retirement precedes age 62.
Service after 18 September 2005: Normal retirement pension reduced by 1/4%
for each calendar month that such pension commences prior to the Normal
Retirement Pension would have commenced.
Disability Benefit
Eligibility Benefit accrued before 18 September 2005: 15 years of service and
permanently disabled.
Benefit Formula Normal Benefit definition
Death Benefit
Eligibility (1) Accruing continuous service and has completed 5 years of service or is 60
years or older
OR
(2) Retired prior to attaining normal retirement age and retired after attaining
age 50
OR
(3) Retired at 60 or older with entitlement to an immediate pension but died
prior to receipt of first pension payment.

information to assess whether they are in accordance with the presentation and disclosure requirements
of accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America.
Accordingly, the objective of an ERISA Section 103(a)(3)(C) audit is not to express an opinion about
whether the financial statements as a whole are presented fairly, in all material respects, in accordance
with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America.
We are required to communicate with those charged with governance regarding, among other matters, the
planned scope and timing of the audit, significant audit findings, and certain internal control-related
matters that we identified during the audit.
Other Matter – Supplemental Schedules Required by ERISA
The supplemental schedules of Schedule H, line 4i – Schedule of Assets (Held at End of Year) at
December 31, 2024, Schedule H, Line 4i – Schedule of Assets (Acquired and Disposed of Within Year) For
the Year Ended December 31, 2024, and Schedule H, line 4j – Schedule of Reportable Transactions For
the Year Ended December 31, 2024, (“supplemental schedules”), are presented for purposes of additional
analysis and are not a required part of the financial statements but are supplementary information
required by the Department of Labor's Rules and Regulations for Reporting and Disclosure under ERISA.
Such information is the responsibility of management and was derived from and relates directly to the
underlying accounting and other records used to prepare the financial statements. The information
included in the supplemental schedules, other than that agreed to or derived from the certified investment
information, has been subjected to the auditing procedures applied in the audit of the financial statements
and certain additional procedures, including comparing and reconciling such information directly to the
underlying accounting and other records used to prepare the financial statements or to the financial
statements themselves, and other additional procedures in accordance with US GAAS. For information
included in the supplemental schedules that agreed to or is derived from the certified investment
information, we compared such information to the related certified investment information.
In forming our opinion on the supplemental schedules, we evaluated whether the supplemental
schedules, other than the information agreed to or derived from the certified investment information,
including their form and content, are presented in conformity with the Department of Labor’s Rules and
Regulations for Reporting and Disclosure under ERISA. In our opinion
• the form and content of the supplemental schedules, other than the information in the
supplemental schedules that agreed to or is derived from the certified investment information,
are presented, in all material respects, in conformity with the Department of Labor’s Rules and
Regulations for Reporting and Disclosure under ERISA.
• the information in the supplemental schedules related to assets held by and certified to by a
qualified institution agrees to, or is derived from, in all material respects, the information
prepared and certified by an institution that management determined meets the requirements of
ERISA Section 103(a)(3)(C).
